articles.headline: Takeover Is Expected For Eye-Care Company
articles.snippet: If completed, a transaction would be one of the biggest health care deals of the year. And it could reap a sizable profit for Bausch & Lomb’s current owner, Warburg Pincus.
articles.abstract: If completed, a transaction would be one of the biggest health care deals of the year. And it could reap a sizable profit for Bausch & Lomb’s current owner, Warburg Pincus.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:13 p.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: The Talk You Didn’t Have With Your Parents Could Cost You
articles.snippet: Children may be reluctant to ask aging parents about their estate and financial affairs, but information shared can prevent confusion later.
articles.abstract: Children may be reluctant to ask aging parents about their estate and financial affairs, but information shared can prevent confusion later.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you haven’t had a conversation with your parents about handling their financial affairs after they die, Krysten Crawford’s tale may spring you into action.

articles.headline: Exxon Defies Calls to Add Gays to Anti-Bias Policy
articles.snippet: More than 88 percent of Fortune 500 companies have adopted written policies prohibiting bias on the basis of sexual orientation, but Exxon Mobil has refused.
articles.abstract: More than 88 percent of Fortune 500 companies have adopted written policies prohibiting bias on the basis of sexual orientation, but Exxon Mobil has refused.
articles.lead_paragraph: For millions of gay and lesbian employees, much has changed since 1999, when no states recognized gay marriage, “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” effectively barred people who were openly gay from serving in the military, Matthew Shepard’s murderer was convicted — and Exxon Mobil shareholders were first asked to protect gay and lesbian employees from discrimination.

articles.headline: Growth in Options Trading Helps Brokers but Not Small Investors
articles.snippet: Brokerage firms say that options, traditionally used by professional traders, can be profitable for ordinary investors, but this does not square with many investors’ experiences.
articles.abstract: Brokerage firms say that options, traditionally used by professional traders, can be profitable for ordinary investors, but this does not square with many investors’ experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the brokerage firms that helped pique American’s interest in stocks are now luring them into something much riskier: stock options.

articles.headline: On the Front Lines of Food Safety
articles.snippet: Fruit growers, farm workers and a major retailer have started a program aimed at preventing the types of bacterial outbreaks that have sickened consumers who ate contaminated produce.
articles.abstract: Fruit growers, farm workers and a major retailer have started a program aimed at preventing the types of bacterial outbreaks that have sickened consumers who ate contaminated produce.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSS LANDING, Calif. — With piles of fresh strawberries beckoning consumers at markets and stores this season, an alliance of a major retailer, fruit growers and farm workers has begun a program to promote healthy produce and improve working conditions.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: For Obama’s Global Vision, Daunting Problems
articles.snippet: Taking America off “perpetual war footing,” as the president proposes to do, will not be a simple task.
articles.abstract: Taking America off “perpetual war footing,” as the president proposes to do, will not be a simple task.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in one of his most significant speeches since taking office, did not simply declare an end to the post-9/11 era on Thursday. He also offered a vision of America’s role in the world that he hopes could be one of his lasting legacies.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Fox Overseer of ‘Idol’ and Its Kin Will Depart
articles.snippet: Mike Darnell, who has supervised reality programming for Fox since before the term reality show entered the lexicon, oversaw “American Idol,” once the most popular show on American TV.
articles.abstract: Mike Darnell, who has supervised reality programming for Fox since before the term reality show entered the lexicon, oversaw “American Idol,” once the most popular show on American TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not only is “American Idol” expected to lose all four of its judges, it is also bidding adieu to Mike Darnell, the Fox executive who judged correctly at the very beginning that the show would be a hit.

articles.headline: Dispute Over Budget Deepens a Rift Within the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Republicans are locked in a dispute over future budget negotiations, splitting along generational and ideological lines on the party’s approach to dealing with the federal debt.
articles.abstract: Republicans are locked in a dispute over future budget negotiations, splitting along generational and ideological lines on the party’s approach to dealing with the federal debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans are locked in a widening internal dispute over future budget negotiations, splitting along generational and ideological lines on the party’s approach to the central issue that drove the conservative surge in the Obama era: how to deal with the federal debt.

articles.headline: States’ Policies on Health Care Exclude Some of the Poorest
articles.snippet: For millions of people below the poverty line, no assistance for health insurance will be available in states that have refused to expand Medicaid.
articles.abstract: For millions of people below the poverty line, no assistance for health insurance will be available in states that have refused to expand Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The refusal by about half the states to expand Medicaid will leave millions of poor people ineligible for government-subsidized health insurance under President Obama’s health care law even as many others with higher incomes receive federal subsidies to buy insurance.

articles.headline: Public Rapes Outrage Brazil, Testing Ideas of Image and Class
articles.snippet: A recent wave of rapes in Rio de Janeiro has cast a spotlight on the conflicted attitudes toward women in a country where many hold positions of power.
articles.abstract: A recent wave of rapes in Rio de Janeiro has cast a spotlight on the conflicted attitudes toward women in a country where many hold positions of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The attacks have stunned this city. In one, an assailant held a gun to the head of a 30-year-old woman while raping her in front of passengers on a bus as the driver proceeded down a main avenue. In another, a 14-year-old girl from a hillside slum was raped on one of Rio’s most famous stretches of beach.

articles.headline: Shareholders Are Speaking Up, but Who’s Listening?
articles.snippet: It’s that time of year when shareholders speak their minds at annual meetings. But that doesn’t mean the companies’ boards are always listening.
articles.abstract: It’s that time of year when shareholders speak their minds at annual meetings. But that doesn’t mean the companies’ boards are always listening.
articles.lead_paragraph: WE are nearing the end of proxy season, that once-a-year moment when shareholders can speak their minds, sort of, to the officers and directors overseeing their companies. But that doesn’t mean corporate boards always listen.

articles.headline:
Hezbollah Commits to an
All-Out Fight to
Save Assad
articles.snippet: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, said that the organization founded to defend Lebanon and fight Israel was entering a new phase, looking abroad to protect its interests.
articles.abstract: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, said that the organization founded to defend Lebanon and fight Israel was entering a new phase, looking abroad to protect its interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of the powerful Lebanese militant group Hezbollah decisively committed his followers on Saturday to an all-out battle in Syria to defeat the rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad. He said the organization, founded to defend Lebanon and fight Israel, was entering “a completely new phase,” sending troops abroad to protect its interests.

articles.headline: Leak Inquiries Show How Wide a Net U.S. Cast
articles.snippet: Details of investigations into government leaks of classified materials also hint at the personal and professional cost for those caught up.
articles.abstract: Details of investigations into government leaks of classified materials also hint at the personal and professional cost for those caught up.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before the F.B.I. conducted 550 interviews of officials and seized the phone records of Associated Press reporters in a leak investigation connected to a 2012 article about a Yemen bomb plot, agents had sought the same reporters’ sources for two other articles about terrorism.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner, Charlie Savage and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Amma’s Multifaceted Empire, Built on Hugs
articles.snippet: Mata Amritanandamayi, known as Amma, is a globe-trotting guru who embraces the masses — and a get-it-done management style for her charities.
articles.abstract: Mata Amritanandamayi, known as Amma, is a globe-trotting guru who embraces the masses — and a get-it-done management style for her charities.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE are entourages — and then there is the retinue of Mata Amritanandamayi, a 59-year-old Indian guru known simply as Amma, or “mother.” On Friday, she began a two-month North American tour during which she will be accompanied by 275 volunteers. They plan to ride in four buses across the continent from Bellevue, Wash., to Marlborough, Mass., visiting 11 cities, including New York. And at each stop along the way, Amma will sit on stage for 15 hours at a stretch, greeting her thousands of devotees.

articles.headline: Last Inspection: Precise Ritual of Dressing Nation’s War Dead
articles.snippet: At the Dover Port Mortuary, where the bodies of service members are brought to be prepared for funeral, no detail is too small, whether the coffin is closed or the body slated for cremation.
articles.abstract: At the Dover Port Mortuary, where the bodies of service members are brought to be prepared for funeral, no detail is too small, whether the coffin is closed or the body slated for cremation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del. — The soldier bent to his work, careful as a diamond cutter. He carried no weapon or rucksack, just a small plastic ruler, which he used to align a name plate, just so, atop the breast pocket of an Army dress blue jacket, size 39R.

articles.headline: California Faces a New Quandary, Too Much Money
articles.snippet: After years of battles over state budget deficits and spending cutbacks, an unexpected surplus has set off a debate about which programs to restore and how long the boon will last.
articles.abstract: After years of battles over state budget deficits and spending cutbacks, an unexpected surplus has set off a debate about which programs to restore and how long the boon will last.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After years of grueling battles over state budget deficits and spending cuts, California has a new challenge on its hands: too much money. An unexpected surplus is fueling an argument over how the state should respond to its turn of good fortune.

articles.headline: U.S. Shift Poses Risk to Pakistan
articles.snippet: An American withdrawal from Afghanistan and the curtailment of the drone campaign could plunge Pakistan’s hotbed tribal areas into further chaos.
articles.abstract: An American withdrawal from Afghanistan and the curtailment of the drone campaign could plunge Pakistan’s hotbed tribal areas into further chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: From multibillion-dollar military aid to stealthy and secretive drone strikes, Pakistan, perhaps even more than Afghanistan, has been the central focus of America’s 12-year war on Islamist militancy.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Areas in Beirut Are Hit
articles.snippet: Four people were wounded in a strike in the Hezbollah-controlled area of southern Beirut, Lebanon, during an attack that seemed linked to the militant group’s growing role in the Syrian war next door.
articles.abstract: Four people were wounded in a strike in the Hezbollah-controlled area of southern Beirut, Lebanon, during an attack that seemed linked to the militant group’s growing role in the Syrian war next door.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two rockets crashed into southern Beirut suburbs controlled by the militant Shiite group Hezbollah on Sunday, wounding four people. The attack, the first on the group’s Beirut stronghold since the hostilities in Syria broke out two years ago, raised anxieties here that the fighting next door was beginning to revive Lebanon’s own sectarian conflicts.

articles.headline: Europeans Press China Over Trade in Telecom
articles.snippet: Officials appear poised to try to settle a dispute over the Chinese telecommunications firms Huawei and ZTE, which were accused of violating antidumping and subsidies laws.
articles.abstract: Officials appear poised to try to settle a dispute over the Chinese telecommunications firms Huawei and ZTE, which were accused of violating antidumping and subsidies laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month in Paris, Ken Hu, the acting chief executive of Huawei, told a group of journalists that the fast-growing Chinese maker of telecommunications network equipment had not come to France to supplant Alcatel-Lucent in its home market.

articles.headline: Al Jazeera America Shifts Focus to U.S. News
articles.snippet: To counter skepticism about its Al Jazeera America cable channel, the Qatar-based network is building a sizable news organization to cover the United States.
articles.abstract: To counter skepticism about its Al Jazeera America cable channel, the Qatar-based network is building a sizable news organization to cover the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: While it has a foreign name, the forthcoming Al Jazeera cable channel in the United States wants to be American through and through.

articles.headline: Israeli Venture Meant to Serve Electric Cars Is Ending Its Run
articles.snippet: Better Place failed to attract many customers to its battery-swapping service plan, and its largest shareholder decided against further investment.
articles.abstract: Better Place failed to attract many customers to its battery-swapping service plan, and its largest shareholder decided against further investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The vision was ambitious. Better Place, an electric vehicle infrastructure company, unveiled plans more than five years ago to pioneer a system of quick-service battery swapping stations across Israel to enable unlimited travel.

articles.headline: Concert Industry Struggles With ‘Bots’ That Siphon Off Tickets
articles.snippet: Digital tools known as “bots” are accused of trying to buy hundreds of thousands of tickets a day, shutting out fans.
articles.abstract: Digital tools known as “bots” are accused of trying to buy hundreds of thousands of tickets a day, shutting out fans.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the summer concert season approaches, music fans and the concert industry that serves them have a common enemy in New York. And in Russia. And in India.

articles.headline: A Legacy Feud in Tech
articles.snippet: The rivalry between two cloud computing upstarts echoes a bitterly fought battle between Oracle and PeopleSoft.
articles.abstract: The rivalry between two cloud computing upstarts echoes a bitterly fought battle between Oracle and PeopleSoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If the Hatfields and McCoys lived in Silicon Valley, they’d be fighting with piles of cash and lines of software code instead of knives and shotguns. And the fight would be over who wins the most customers in the computer industry’s growing “cloud” of software services.

articles.headline: Groups Targeted by I.R.S. Tested Rules on Politics
articles.snippet: An examination of nonprofit applicants revealed activities that tax experts and former Internal Revenue Service officials said would provide a basis for closer review.
articles.abstract: An examination of nonprofit applicants revealed activities that tax experts and former Internal Revenue Service officials said would provide a basis for closer review.
articles.lead_paragraph: When CVFC, a conservative veterans’ group in California, applied for tax-exempt status with the Internal Revenue Service, its biggest expenditure that year was several thousand dollars in radio ads backing a Republican candidate for Congress.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Partisan Gridlock Thwarts Effort to Alter Health Law
articles.snippet: Republicans want the entire law repealed and most of them will not take part in even routine tweaks, and Democrats fear reopening a politically charged debate as midterm elections near.
articles.abstract: Republicans want the entire law repealed and most of them will not take part in even routine tweaks, and Democrats fear reopening a politically charged debate as midterm elections near.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he talks to Republicans in Congress, Scott DeFife, a restaurant industry lobbyist, speaks their language: President Obama’s health care law is a train wreck well down the track. There will be collateral damage if changes are not made. Friends of the industry cannot sit back and let that happen.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Who Owns This Land? In Greece, Who Knows?
articles.snippet: With no national land registry in the country, competing claims abound and taxes remain unpaid in a system based on handwritten ledgers.
articles.abstract: With no national land registry in the country, competing claims abound and taxes remain unpaid in a system based on handwritten ledgers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Not long ago Leonidas Hamodrakas, a lawyer in Athens, decided to pay closer attention to his family’s land holdings — some fields, a scattering of buildings and a massive stone tower — in Mani, a rural region in southern Greece.

articles.headline: One-Day Deals Making E-Books Brief Best Sellers
articles.snippet: Flash sales have taken hold in the book business, helping older books soar from the backlist to the best-seller list.
articles.abstract: Flash sales have taken hold in the book business, helping older books soar from the backlist to the best-seller list.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Sunday this month, the crime thriller “Gone, Baby, Gone,” by Dennis Lehane, sold 23 e-book copies, a typically tiny number for a book that was originally published in 1998 but has faded into obscurity.

articles.headline: Seeking Food Ingredients That Aren’t Gene-Altered
articles.snippet: Consumers are driving a movement toward labeling food products made from genetically modified organisms, and food producers are responding.
articles.abstract: Consumers are driving a movement toward labeling food products made from genetically modified organisms, and food producers are responding.
articles.lead_paragraph: Food companies big and small are struggling to replace genetically modified ingredients with conventional ones.

articles.headline: Buyout Offer Brings China Into the Orbit of Club Med
articles.snippet: A Chinese conglomerate, Fosun International, is playing an unusually visible role in the proposed acquisition of Club Méditerranée, a famous European brand.
articles.abstract: A Chinese conglomerate, Fosun International, is playing an unusually visible role in the proposed acquisition of Club Méditerranée, a famous European brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: 7:52 p.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner, Neil Gough and Keith Bradsher
